Award.AwardTitle: Imaging Defect Dynamics in Organic Semiconductor Films
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Description: The goal of this research project is to apply novel scanning probe microscopy tools to understand how local structure and disorder influence photochemical stability and charge transfer state formation in organic semiconductor films. To accomplish this goal, the project uses new experimental capabilities such as time-resolved electrostatic force microscopy to make direct nanoscale correlations between local structural disorder and local variations in photochemical trap formation, doping, and interfacial charge transfer state energies. These observations can add a unique perspective to our understanding of how structure and processing affect the photochemistry and photophysics of organic semiconductors with technological implications for photodiodes and photovoltaics. The project tackles three challenges related to the overall goal: (1) using sub-microsecond time-resolved electrostatic force microscopy methods to study the role of heterogeneity and local disorder on the photochemical degradation of state-of-the art high-efficiency organic bulk heterojunctions; (2) understanding the role of local structure and disorder on local carrier transport, photochemical doping, and the evolution of these photochemical processes in time using non-contact energy dissipation (quality factor) measurements; and (3) understanding the role of morphology and structural heterogeneity on the energetic distribution of charge transfer states in a spatially and spectrally resolved fashion.

Non-Technical Description: Organic semiconductors are currently used in electronic displays, and are of interest for use as light-weight, low-cost solar cells (for instance to power and recharge consumer electronics, or eventually harvest solar energy for the grid). Long term stability is a major challenge for these applications, and this project seeks to better understand the details of how imperfections and defects form in these materials at very fine length scales of tens of nanometers through the application of newly developed scanning-probe microscopy tools. The possible applications of organic semiconductors in lighting and solar energy not only have significant direct economic and societal impact, but can be valuable hooks for engaging students and the broader public in science education. The outreach component of the project develops new digital and visual media for large scale public engagements reaching K-12 students and the local community. In addition to training graduate students at the interface of chemistry, physics, and materials science, the project directly supports undergraduate research and seeks to address science education pipeline issues by beginning a new partnership with the Rainier Scholars program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes for NSF DMR-1306079:

“Imaging Defect Dynamics in Organic Semiconductor Films”

Organic semiconductors are currently used in electronic displays, and are also of interest for use as light-weight, low-cost solar cells (for instance to power and recharge consumer electronics such as phones or tablets, or eventually harvest solar energy for the grid). Long term stability is a major challenge for these applications, and this project helped to better understand the fundamental science details of how imperfections and defects form in these materials at very fine length scales through the application of newly developed scanning-probe microscopy tools.

While previous studies had looked at the relationship between film structure and device operation, this study provided important new data regarding the relationship between nanoscale film structure and the lifetime and degradation processes occurring in organic semiconductor films. To accomplish this goal, this Division of Materials Research grant performed high-resolution imaging studies of degradation on organic photovoltaic films using atomic force microscopy (AFM) techniques. AFM is a widespread technique for acquiring nanometer-resolution images far beyond the limit of conventional microscopes and is ideally suited for studying soft organic semiconductor materials. Under this grant our group developed a new AFM method (cantilever ringdown imaging) for measuring degradation, and we also significantly improved another AFM method known as time-resolved electrostatic force microscopy (trEFM) by demonstrating measurements of extremely low efficiency regions in an organic semiconductor film.

Cantilever ringdown imaging measures the change in the AFM cantilever’s energy dissipation with nanometer resolution. Dissipation is a measure of how much energy the AFM tip loses during the imaging process at each pixel, and it is strongly affect by electrostatic interactions with the AFM tip. Dissipation is affected by how difficult it is to move charges through a film or how much they may be slowed due to degradation-induced traps.

While dissipation can be qualitatively measured in conventional electrostatic force microscopy, we developed the cantilever ringdown imaging method that measures the change in dissipation in a more quantitative manner, and, most importantly, connected the dissipation measurements to changes in the photochemical degradation of the film. Using cantilever ringdown, we observed that dissipation is fastest in areas of a polymer:fullerene film that have the highest fullerene concentration. As a result, creating films with more intermixed morphologies—say, by using a solvent additive during fabrication— could be used to yield more stable films by inhibiting formation of deleterious fullerene clusters.

Lastly, under this grant we used trEFM to investigate the local variations in low-energy charge transfer (CT) state populations in a photovoltaic film. This experiment is particularly challenging because CT state absorption is low and the signal is thus difficult to detect – even in life-sized device experiment. Importantly, it was a significant achievement under this award to show that trEFM can measure these CT state absorptions in small areas in a microscope experiment, which equates to a current detection sensitivity on the order of attoamps (~10-18 Amperes).

The possible applications of organic semiconductors in displays, lighting and solar energy not only have significant direct economic and societal impact, but can be valuable hooks for engaging students and the broader public in science education. The outreach component of the project developed new digital and visual media for large scale public engagements reaching K-12 students and the local community. In addition to training graduate students at the interface of chemistry, physics, and materials science, the project directly supported undergraduate research and sought to address science education pipeline issues by beginning a new partnership with the Rainier Scholars program. All of the software for the microscopy techniques used under the award is publicly available on a code repository. Our group hosted students from other universities wanting to learn how we perform these experiments. We have also been working with the supplier to help other research labs adopt these methods. As a result, we expect these methods like cantilever ringdown imaging of dissipation as well as time-resolved electrostatic force microscopy to see wider use in the coming years.
